Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. MURAL ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: Abbey sits in front of cameras with JEFFREY MORGAN. Several members of her staff and Jeffrey's parents sit behind the camera. Production staff adjust lights and apply makeup.

Dialogues.Line: I don't want you to be nervous.
Okay.
If you're nervous I'll detect it and mock you mercilessly on national television.
Okay.

Sure, some people think it's cool for the First Lady to mock a 14 year old boy who's only crime is getting nervous, talking on television in front of millions and millions of people, but hey, I'm gonna do it anyway.
[nods] Okay, I understand.
Jeffery...
Yes, Ma'am?
I was kidding. [Jeffrey laughs.] Now, if you do get nervous, just look at me or look at your parents.
Okay.
But you're not gonna get nervous, are you?
[shakes head] Nope.
[smiles] If you do I'll beat your brains out.
[smiles] Yes, Ma'am.
[smiles] Not me personally 'cause I have people who do that for me. But you get the idea.
Mrs. Bartlet, ten seconds.
[loudly] Lilly, should have worn gray today!
You're good. Abbey shakes off tension and faces the camera.

Twenty-five minutes past the hour and 42 degrees outside our Rockefeller Center studios. Abigail Bartlet is no stranger to the fight for children's health around the world. And she's taken the time to speak with us this morning. Good morning, Mrs. Bartlet.
Good Morning, Melissa.
You're speaking to us from the Mural Room, is that right?

That's right. [looks at Jeffery] And I'm here to introduce this young man on my left, Jeffery Morgan. Jeffery helped opened my eyes to the issue of child labor exploitation around the world. Abbey's chief of staff, LILLY MAYS, watches for a moment and walks out to the HALLWAY.
Now Jeffery, you started your organization because of pen pal you felt was in trouble.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. COMMUNICATION'S BULLPEN - DAY
Scenes.Description: Sam stands watching the program on a monitor. Lilly walks up to him.

Dialogues.Line: Yes, and I thought that...
[confused] When did Jeffery happen?
Sam...
Lilly, when did Jeffery happen?
I dug it up for her yesterday. You're gonna love him.
Let's find out. They watch the monitor.
Your organization, the Kids Crusade...
The Children's Crusade.
The Children...I'm sorry. The Children's Crusade was created when your pen pal was sold into slavery, is that right?
Well, that's not they call it in India, but that's what it is. You see, Panshant's mother borrowed $25. And Panshant had to go to work to pay back the loan.
He's good.
Yeah.
She borrowed the money from what we would call a loan shark, Melissa. Then Panshant was bonded to work for the loan shark. But he never paid back the loan because he... SAM looks at a newspaper.
And here's my thing.
What?
What would you guys think about the President not going to the Hill to the Budget Meeting but bringing the leadership to the White House instead?
Why?
We want the news cycle.
[looks up from the paper] Lilly?
She's got the National Press Club tomorrow. It's her first major speech since Commencement Season. It's child labor and we want the news cycle.
[reads the paper] News cycle doesn't belong to us, Lilly. It's not ours to give away.
You know what I'm talking about.
We want to show that the President is reaching out to Congress for a Budget compromise. He's literally going to Congress.
He's being driven 6 blocks in a stretch limo, Sam. It's not like he's Henry Clay.
It's a symbol.
Your guy steps out of a motorcade and it's three column inches above the fold. My guy is page 23.
Your guy's married to our guy and our guy won an election. That's something you people are gonna have to get used to.
Your guy has a 48% approval rating. My guy's at 61. And bite me.
Ah, point well argued. [goes back to reading the paper]
Mrs. Bartlet, does the company know its subcontractors are using child labor?
Melissa, if they don't then they're criminally negligent. If they do then they're simply criminal.
[pointing at the TV] There it is!
That was a pretty good pitch to inning.
Come on Sam, see Toby. Give us some room to run!
Lilly...
[walks out of his office] Change the channel.
Toby...
[to Lilly] Hi. [to Sam] Change to Channel 5.
What happened?
Bernie Dahl died. Toby walks back in his office. They stare at him for a moment.
Eighty hours a week in darkness and violence.... Sam grabs the remote and changes channels.

...suffering what is being described as a massive heart attack was pronounced dead upon arrival at Johns Hopkins Medical Center. Mr. Dahl, widely respected on Wall Street as the chief architect of the longest peacetime economic expansion in history, was in a fourth year of his second four year term as Chairman of the Federal Reserve.
You just lost your news cycle.

Scenes.Scene Heading: SMASH CUT TO: MAIN TITLES
FADE IN: INT. OVAL OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Bartlet sits with two Intelligence advisors.

Dialogues.Line: [reading] Is here going to be a coup?
Excuse me, sir?
Is there going to be a coup?
Uh, no sir. We believe the new few weeks the Abida Kahn will appoint their successors from diverse regions and groups, including the Ebo from the East. Leo wanders in and stands in the doorway.
They've been complainting of under representation.
And this is on page....
17... In your classified book.
Page 17. They page through.
Excuse me... Mr. President.
Yeah? [looks up] Oh. [to advisors] Excuse me, please. [gets up and walks over to Leo] Leo... Intelligence briefing.
I know.
There are mornings I'm just nodding my head. That can't be good for anybody.
Bernie Dahl had a heart attack.
No!
Yeah. He died about an hour ago...
[shocked] He died?!?
...on the way to the hospital. Bad timing.
I'll say. Who knows so far?
We got it off the news.
Dammit.
Yeah.
[looks at his watch] The market is going to open 200 points down.
If we're lucky.
When was the last time we were lucky?
Super Tuesday.
It's going to be 300...350.
Announce Ron Ehrlich.
Not yet.
Announce Ron Ehrlich as Dahl's successor.
Not... yet.
You do it this morning when trading opens everyone calms down.
I'm not saying I'm not sure it's Ehrlich.
Sir...
I'm saying I'm not sure. It's the Fed Chairman. Give me a day.
It's gonna be an expensive day.
How expensive.
You say 300 points. It could be more.
Wall Street needs to trust me.
Should I go tell them that?
A day. I'll tell you something else. You could have been nicer to me during this conversation.
How?
By saying that Wall Street does trust me and the market will hold until I appoint a new Fed Chairman.
Sure. Just give me a minute to call my broker and dump my portfolio.
I'm taking the day.
I'm going to leak it, sir, on account in the next hour people will calm things down.
No.
Mr. President!
I'm not ready to jump into bed with Ron Ehrlich yet. I'm one of the few people in my family who can say that.
Yes, sir. The advisors stand as Bartlet walks back over to them.
So... [sits] That's was page 17? The advisors sit.
Yes, sir. The Leader of the National Assembly...

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. WHITE HOUSE - DAY
CUT TO: INT. JOSH'S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Josh leans back in his chair, phone to his ear. Donna walks in.

Dialogues.Line: So, I've been reading this book.
I'm...on the phone.
You're on hold!
How do you know?
The light was blinking.
[glares at the blinking light] What book?
It's about what life was like 100 years ago.
Donna, the fact that I'm on hold right now this shouldn't be your cue to tell me what like was like 100 years ago.
For instance... [Josh sighs.] A hundred years ago most women bathed once a month and they used borax or egg yolks for shampoo.
[sits up quickly] I'm here. [turns his head away from Donna]
Florence and Bertha were among the top ten names given girls.
I'm meeting with them in 5mintues. Toby's gonna be fine.
Today they don't make the top ten thousand.
Excuse me. [to Donna] What?? [holds the phone against his forehead]
Florence and Bertha aren't among the top ten thousands names today yet only a ....
I'm actually back on the phone now.
I'll wait. [sits on the arm of a chair]
Toby's gonna be fine. Don't worry about it. [hangs up and puts on his suit coat] Toby's in his office?
Yeah. Population of Las Vegas, Nevada... [Josh stares at her.] ...was 22.
I'm gonna go to my meeting now. But you sit here and keeping talking. It'll be like I never left. [grabs papers and walks around his desk]
Here. [stands up and hands him a folder]
Thank you. Josh walks out with Donna in pursuit. They wander through JOSH'S BULLPEN AREA.
And you know what else?
What?
Drive-by shootings were a problem in Denver.
100 years ago?
Yeah!
What were they driving?
I'm glad you asked.
Horses!
Young boys on horseback riding through town shooting at, I suppose...stagecoaches and whatnot.
[drops off mail] When do you have time to read these books?!?
It's important to make time just for yourself, Josh.
I notice you're able to do it right here at the office.
I'm adaptable.
Among other things. Donna smiles as Josh walks off.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. TOBY'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Sam paces outside Toby's door. Toby sits inside writing on a pad and munching antacids.

Dialogues.Line: Sam?
Yeah? [walks in]
C.J. gonna need a reason why the President's waiting a day that doesn't sound like we're reconsidering Ehrlich.
I just gave her one.
What?
Respect.
[sighs] The man just died... out of respect for his memory... his family...
It would be wrong to name a successor on the day he...
Respect works.
[sighs] Tell you this though, I'm going to the gym today. [paces]
Okay that didn't seem to be about anything that interests me.
I'm just saying. Bernie Dahl has a heart attack, BAM!.... right out of nowhere.
It's his fifth heart attack Sam. He was 138 years old. [munches antacids]
Yeah but these are highly stressful jobs. I haven't been to the gym in three weeks.
Sam, look at yourself. How much healthier do you want to be?
I'm just saying if anybody need me at lunch I'm gonna be at the gym. And that's gonna be sad for me because I'm gonna live longer than you.
Don't count on it. Sam leaves. Josh runs up.
[gloomy] Hey.
Hey. [steps in] Toby....
We are waiting a day to make our announcement out of respect, Josh.
For whom?
The dead.
Oh.
And how I wish I were one of them.
Now...You're gonna love this meeting!
Betcha I'm not.
Toby....
It's locked down.
I know that!
[loudly] It's locked down with some 15 votes to spare.
There is value for having these three Congressmen on board.
What is it?
A... A clear and public demonstration that the President's liberal base hasn't turned their backs. Toby gets up and walks behind his desk.
[smiles] In the case of these three people, I'd like to see a clear and public demonstration that they've turned their backs and run as far as humanly possible.
I think you think it's beneath you to ask.

[yelling] It is beneath me to ask. It's sown up! By 15. [Josh looks around nervously.] [yelling] We've got the trade bill. It's sewn up! And it's as bipartisan as we're likely to see. There was a victory and we're the victors. And I'm not going in there hat in my hands.
No one's asking you too.
[yelling] You're asking me too! Josh walks in and closes the door.
No, we're gonna do good cop, bad cop.
No...we're really not.
Why not?
Cause this isn't an episode of Hawaii 5-0. How about you be the good cop, I'll be the cop who didn't go to the meeting.
You have to go to the meeting. I told them you would be at the meeting. If you're not there they're gonna start right out insulted. Josh heads to the door and opens it for Toby.
I go to this meeting there's a decent chance we end this meeting with them insulted. So... [grabs the antacids]
Let's go. Josh opens the door for Toby. They exit into the COMUNICATION'S OFFICE.
I need to exercise more.
Toby...
I gotta exercise more. I gotta eat better. Toby munches antacids. They pause in the doorway.

Toby, you're gonna sit in that room and you're gonna behave yourself. I swear to God, you are gonna sit there while I court these peoples votes and every so often you're gonna smile so as to indicate warmth.
I can still kick the crap outta you, though. We're clear on that, right?
Yeah.
Then what the heck are we waiting for? Josh eyes Toby warily. Toby munches the antacids.
Toby...
I'll be nice.
The President's very serious about this.
He shouldn't be.
So you've told him many times but here these people are. So, I guess the President disagrees with you... Given that...
I understand. Let's go. JOSH sticks out his chin and glares at Toby. They exit into the HALLWAY.
So you're just gonna sit there.
Yeah.
If you open your mouth it will be to say something nice.
Yes. Josh looks doubtful.
Come on. Josh pauses at the door and eyes Toby before they enter THE ROOSEVELT ROOM.
[whispers] It's sewn up, Josh.
[whispers] Whatever.
[whispers] By 15 votes.
Morning.
Morning.
How are you? Josh walks over and shakes the hands of the Congressmen.
Good.
Nice to see you. Thanks for coming.
Josh, how are you? Toby sits sullenly at the table, munching antacids.
How you been?

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. BRIEFING ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: C.J. is at the podium.

Dialogues.Line: He is shocked and saddened by the death of his colleague. For over 11 years Bernard Dahl oversaw the largest economic expansion in the country's history and I can assure you he will be....
[shouting] C.J.! C.J.!
...missed. [sighs] Katie?
Is Ron Ehrlich the new Fed Chair?
There are a number of very good candidates.
Who's on the short list?
I want to be clear, no such list exists. Obviously from his post as the number two man at the Federal Reserve, Ron Ehrlich is a candidate.
Sidney Bloom?
Sidney Bloom is a candidate.
Lawrence Ottenberg?
Mr. Ottenberg is a candidate.
C.J., Mrs. Bartlet's declared a preference for Ron Ehrlich. To what extent do you think that's going to weigh in on the President's decision?
[looks caught off-guard] I'm aware of no such declaration.
It's in a wire piece. 'Unnamed people close the First Lady' are saying she hoped the President would appoint Ron Ehrlich when Bernie Dahl's term expired.
I don't know who the unnamed people are. But I suppose it's possible on a social occasion...
C.J., when's the President going to name the new Chairman?
We're hoping to have it done tomorrow.
Why the delay?
[solemnly] Respect.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - DAY
Scenes.Description: C.J. and Carol exit the Briefing Room.

Dialogues.Line: Get me a copy of the wire report?
On your desk.
Could I have sounded any stupider saying respect?
You were fine! Sam approaches from the other direction with his gym bag.
Sam.
Yeah?
I need you.
I'm going to the gym. C.J. turns and walks back with him.
I got a question about Mrs. Bartlet stating her preference for Ron Ehrlich. They stop walking in the lobby doorway.
Publically?
It's in a wire piece that's on my desk. Ginger walks by.
Ginger! [throws his gym bag to her]
Back to your office?
Yep! Ginger walks off with the bag.
Thank you! C.J. pats him on the arm. They head off in different directions.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LILLY'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Lilly is on the phone. A staffer sits across the desk.

Dialogues.Line: She was fantastic this morning and I can promise you that was just the opening salvo. First Lady is gonna lead the charge against Child Labor. [whispers to staffer] There's some index cards on Patty's desk . I need them for the ride over. The staffer gets up and leaves as Sam enters.
Hi.
Hi.

Yeah, she'll do Larry King tonight then go to St Louis. Yeah, call me back later and I'll give you 10 minutes. [hangs up.] Did you see the rest of the interview? She stands and shuffles through papers.
I didn't.
Jeffery and his classmates raised enough money for Panshant and everyone in their village to get out of debt.
Well that solves that, then.
Abbey's running with the ball, Sam.
And I just want to make sure we're the ones calling the plays in the huddle, Lilly.
What's the problem?
C.J. got a question regarding the First Lady's preference for Ron Ehrlich.
Her preference is fairly well known, Sam. I don't think...
This time it was in a wire piece...'Sources close to Mrs. Bartlet'.
I don't know anything about it.
It wasn't you...
I just said I didn't know anything about it.
Okay, we'll let you know when we want something leaked. You know that, right?
[angry] Sam, I standing here telling you and I'm telling you that I don't know anything about it. And if C.J. wants to come up here and call me a liar...
C.J. didn't come up here, I did. No one's calling you a liar. Lilly puts down the papers and buttons her suitcoat.
We've gotta find a way for our two staffs to work together better than this.
No we don't. We need to find a way for your staff to work better with our staff.
Well, that's the spirit, Sam.
Look, I'm...
[coldly] I'm late for a speech. [walks out angrily]
Lilly? The Staffer rushes back in and looks through some folders on a table.
[quietly] That was a nice bit of diplomacy I... just did there. [The staffer looks at him.] That's good. [to staffer] I'm going to the gym now.
Okay! [leaves]
Okay. Sam shakes his head and walks out, hands on pockets.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: EXT. WHITE HOUSE - DAY
CUT TO: INT. OVAL OFFICE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Bartlet stands behind his desk talking to Leo. C.J. stares at them.

Dialogues.Line: Without regard to the validity of past arguments.
That the National Debt was so high it required us to suck up to the bond market.
Yes and I'm saying that condition doesn't exist anymore.
Well, maybe so.

Historically, American prosperity has been built the broad growth in the GDP of 5% of greater. And now with the deflationary pressures of the Global Economy, that kind of growth can be achieved without the negative side affects of rampant inflation. [to C.J.] Do you understand what I'm saying? C.J. starts to open her mouth.
C.J. doesn't understand a word you're saying.
I understand the [something French]. I get the basic [more French] of what you're saying. [Leo and Bartlet smile at each other.] I really don't understand anything.
My point is Ron Ehrlich might not be the guy. I'm saying it's not a mortal lock.
So let me suggest, Mr. President, that I talk to the First Lady and ask her to clarify...
[shakes head] No...
...that her position...
No, no...
"My husband will choose the best man for the Fed...."
[shakes head] Noooo...
..." I support whatever..." Sir!
C.J., we don't handle my wife. When we try, do you know what happens at the other end of this building? [smiles]
You get a little punishment.
I get a little punishment. Screw it. Let's move on. It's not a big deal. [walks behind his desk]
Yes, sir. Leo looks at C.J.
[to C.J.] But try to find out who those friends of my wife's are in the wire piece and take them out back and have them shot. [to Leo] Can I do that?
Yeah.
Yeah, Leo says I can do that. It's gonna be Phyllis who has never liked me. It's gonna be Susan who thinks I'm xenophobic because I don't like Mexican food. These are my wife's friends.
[walks in] Mr. President...
Yes. [to Leo and C.J.] It could be our old next-door neighbors Herb and Marjorie Douglas. [Mrs. Landingham frowns at him.] They're still angry at me 'cause I accidentally ran them over with my car.
Zoey's here.
Thank you, Mrs. Landingham. Mrs. Landingham leaves the door open as she exits.
Anything else?
No.
Thank you, Mr. President.
Thank you, C.J. C.J. leaves.

I'll tell you what else; historically 2 to 2 Ohm GDP expansion is classified lack luster even anemic economic growth. [walks towards the open door] Four Ohm to 5% is needed just to be considered robust and not even spectacular.
[confused] You know, sometimes I don't know what you're talking about.
Sometimes I'm just making it up. Zoey steps in.
Hello, sweetheart.
Dad.
[kisses Zoey on the cheek.] You used to go to school in overalls with a little hat. [closes the door]
Yes, I used to be five.
What's up, Zoey?
Just keeping it real.
[confused] Hmm?
Who the hell knows? [gives her a hug]
Anything else?
No.
Thank you, Mr. President.
Thank you, Leo. Leo walks out to his office.
What you got today?
I got Intro to Cinema and 19th Century Studies.
How about math. Why aren't you taking math?
Cause I graduated High School. Zoey and Bartlet sit on the couch.

Wiseass all you want, but you're coming of age in the 21st century. A century in which I promise you mathematics is going to play a starring role. On the other hand I would definitely put my shoulder into Intro to Cinema. Intro to Cinema's what got me where I am today.
Did you call me over to make fun of me?
That was going to be a big part of my day. [gives her the books back]
Dad...
I met with Butterfield and some Secret Service Agents this morning.
What did I do?
You didn't do anything. They think you should be taking more math.
[laughs] Dad...
It's time for me to tell you about some letters we've been getting.
[worried] Threats?
[frowns] Yeah. They don't like that the daughter of the President is dating a young black man.
Charlie?
Zoey, please don't tell me you're dating more than one guy.
[concerned] No.
Ok.
What is...
Cause one guy for you is actually one more than I'm comfortable with.
So you've said.
I could see it's had a real impact on you.
How bad are the letters?
No worse than any of the stuff they intercept.
Except these are from White Supremists?

Yeah. Why did Butterfield and the guys meet with me? Apparently there's National Convention of some sort in Virginia. It was in the papers yesterday that you and Charlie are going to some club opening this weekend.
You want me to cancel?
You don't have to cancel, but you can't bring Charlie.
[frowns] Okay.
You want me to tell him?
[looks down] We're meeting for lunch. I'll tell him.
You gotta tell him he truth Zoey. Don't make something up.
[laughs] He's not gonna like it.
You sure you don't want me to come?
Yeah. Mrs. Landingham knocks and enters.
Okay.
Mr. President...
Yeah?
The Assistant Secretary of Treasury.
Okay. [to Zoey] You gotta go. Zoey and Bartlet rise.
Hey, I'm sorry about Bernie Dahl.
I never really new him that well. They walk to the door.
Is Ron Ehrlich gonna be the new Fed Chair?
I don't know. You want the job?
Yeah.
Can't have it. Know why?
Why?
Not enough math. Bye. He kisses her on the cheek and she leaves.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. ROOSEVELT ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: Josh and Toby sits across the table from the congressmen and their aides. Toby slowly dunks a teabag and looks bored.

Dialogues.Line: Josh, we're Democrats. Since when do we like lower taxes?

We don't. We like lower tariffs. Lower tariffs on everything from Indian textiles, to German cars to Chilean wines negotiated by our trade reps in Geneva with 130 other countries over the past 7 years. Global Free Trade Markets Access Act now has cleared the President and we're very proud it's finally ready to be voted on by the House.
[stares at the teabag] Where it will win by the way by some 15 votes.
[patiently] Thank you, Toby.
Anyone eating that donut?

[pause, to Toby] All yours. [To the Congressmen] Now, what happens when you lower the cost of something, Economists of every stripe, including the one in the Oval Office, say you that you get a more efficient allotment of economic resources. Now that may not sound like much to you and me but to an Economist that's a week in St. Barts.
Josh, there's no reason to talk to us like were 12.
Josh, we're very concerned about the effect cheaper goods flowing into this country will have on American Labor and American Manufacturing. We're concerned about the lack of environmental controls.
Concerns which are entirely reasonable.
You're concerned about American labor and manufacturing?
Yeah.
What kind of car do you drive?
Toyota.
Then shut up. Josh frowns and covers his face. The congressmen stare in shock at Toby.
Excuse me? Josh rubs his eyes. Toby calmly drinks his tea.
What Toby meant to say is we don't get to see you guys often...[smiles] and it's a crying shame. C.J. knocks on the window. Josh looks over his shoulder at her. He turns back to the Congressmen.
[smiles] Hey everybody, sit tight. We're just getting started. [gets up and heads for the door] Uh, think about what you'd like to eat for lunch.
[slowly gets up, smiles] Also think about that we won and we're here still courting your vote for reasons passing understanding. Josh walks back and takes him by the arm.
Get out here. They exit into the HALLWAY. C.J. waits as Josh backs out the door. Toby follows.
This... right here. This is why you have a reputation as a pain in the ass.
I've cultivated that reputation.
Could I get you to try harder in there? C.J. stares at them.
Sure, cause right now I'm not trying at all.
Guys, I'm standing here. I don't know if you've....
Yeah?
The wire has a piece. It'll be picked up. 'Sources close to the First Lady say that she'...
Ron Ehrlich?
Yeah.
Who are the sources?
I don't know. Sam spoke to Lilly. She doesn't know a thing about it.
Is it Lilly?
Yeah. Josh snickers.
Mrs. Bartlet should slide in and step in the back door. 'Ron Ehrlich is an old friend but she supports whatever'...
Yeah. She's not going to unless someone tells her to.
[loudly] Well, that sounds an awful lot like your job, C.J.
Well, I was just in there and he doesn't want me to handle the First Lady.
Did he say he didn't want you to 'handle the First lady cause he didn't want you to' or did he say it like 'handle the First Lady but I'm not the one who told you to?'
That's what I don't know.
You gotta learn the signs.
I've got most of the signs.
You don't have that one!
I'm learning that one.
Where's Sam?
He went to the gym.
Page Sam and tell him I want him to talk to Lilly again.
What if the President meant it?
[sighs] We're not handling Mrs. Bartlet. We're talking to her staff. Page Sam.
I know most of the signs.
Go! C.J. walks off.
So what would you have done if the guy told you he drove and American car?
Find some other way of humiliating him.
You like winning, don't you?
Saves you from having to say the word please.
Let's go. [walks back in]
Absolutely. [follows]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. GYM - DAY
Scenes.Description: Sam is lifting weights as his pager goes off. He seats the weights and sits up, banging his head on the bar.

Dialogues.Line: Ow! As he picks up his pager, Congresswoman BECKY REESEMAN walks over.
You Alright?
Ah, Congresswoman...yes. I'm fine, thanks.
I heard the clang and the ow. I figured it must be Sam Seaborn.
I'm just trying to get healthy.
How's your head?
I'm fine.
Listen, I actually came over here for a different reason.
[stands] How can I help you?
Um... Can I talk to you over there for a second? They walk over to a corner.
Congresswoman?
'Becky's' fine.
[laughs] Okay.
Where are you guys on the trade bill?
Josh and Toby say we're 15 votes up.
Oh, yeah?
Yeah, we're meeting with some friends of your right now to try to run up the score.
Uh, I want you to know I'm talking to you right now as a courtesy.
Okay.
There's no obligation for me to come to you.
Okay.
Any my coming to you and telling you is not an invitation to try to talk me out of it. So I...
Becky, tell me you're not offering an amendment.
I am.
Becky...
Child Labor restrictions.
You can't.
The First Lady blew the trumpet.
She didn't...
Sam, she did it on television. Given my record I can't be left out of it.
You're not being left of anything.
Sam, I'm talking to you as a courtesy.
This is why we fast tracked this to avoid this kind...
I'm talking to you...
I understand....
I'm talking to you as a courtesy...
This is gonna blow the vote outta the water. Joshua and Toby have a hard nose count that puts us over...

I'm talking to you as a courtesy, Sam. I'm introducing the amendment tonight. Josh and Toby are just gonna have to count again. [looks at his forehead] You should put some ice on that head. She wanders off leaving. Sam looks frustrated.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. PRESS ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: Danny Concannon is on the phone. Leo walks up.

Dialogues.Line: [into phone] ...Free Market Access Act. The GFTMAA.
Danny?
Joanie, I'll call you back.
You don't have to get off.
No problem. [hangs up]
Take a walk with me. I'm on my way out. They walk through JOSH'S BULLPEN AREA.
Say Leo, I noticed the market opened 320 points down.
We noticed that ourselves.
You see it's rebounding.
Yes.
Not very fast.
It'll be fine.
The President needs to name a new Fed Chair.
We will.
I got a half year's salary in technology stocks is what I'm saying.
I had a hunch.
What do you need?
The President was wondering if you have a few minutes to spare at the end of the day.
[stops abruptly, confused] Yeah.

[looks around for Danny and turns back] It'll just be you. It'll be informal and off the record. They'll be a reception at five for the Michigan Women's Democratic Caucus. He'll step out for a few minutes. Danny looks at Leo suspiciously.
What?
Well it sounds like...
Like the place will be lousy with female Democrats?
Yeah.
Yeah.
Ok.
Thanks. Leo leaves. Danny turns as spots C.J. entering the lobby.
Hey.
Hello, Daniel.
How you doing?
I don't have time to talk to you now.
Okay. Danny leaves. C.J. walks up to Sam as he enters the building with his gym bag.
Sam?
Yeah?
I paged you.
Yeah. I got your page and thanks. I hit my head. Becky Reeseman came over. I've got to talk to Josh and Toby.
I need you for a second first.
What is it? They stop.
I mentioned the wire piece to the President.
What did he say?
He said he doesn't want the First Lady handled.
Did he mean it or did he mean he wants you...
[sighs] I don't know.
I don't have that sign.
You gotta pick up the signs.
I've got most all of them.
Yeah well, it's an important one to learn.
Toby thinks if you talk to Lilly Mays again...
Clarification.
Staffer to Staffer. Gently nudge her in that direction.
Yeah, all right. Where are Josh and Toby?
They're still in their meeting.
[walks off] Gotta learn the signs, C.J..
I know! [leaves]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. ROOSEVELT ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: They're still sitting around that table.

Dialogues.Line: Can you deny that the fact that you can buy a British made Range Rover has hurt Ford to some degree?
No, but....
I can.
Toby... [sighs]
I can deny it. Range Rover inspired Ford to design the Explorer. Which is the best selling vehicle in its class and Ford's most successful model in years. Sam knocks on the door.
Will you excuse us for a moment? Josh and Toby get up to leave.
Are we keeping you two from something more important?
Many... many things. The Congressmen look in surprise as they exit. Out in the HALLWAY, Sam waits outside as Josh backs out the door again. Toby follows.
I have to say if there's been improvement in your attitude, it's marginal.
We're in hour number four, you understand.
Guys...
Yeah?
I thought you were at the gym.
I was. And then Becky Reeseman came over to talk to me. She made it very clear it was just a courtesy.
What'd she say?
She's attaching...
No!
She's attaching a Child Labor Amendment.
To what?
[sighs] To this.
She can't!
She is.
When?
Tonight.
This is why we fast tracked it!
She's on ways and Means. Josh groans and turns away.
She was serious? This wasn't one of her funny jokes?
She was inspired by the First Lady. She thought this morning there were trumpets and she doesn't want to...
There were trumpets?
The trumpets called...The trumpets sounded...
What the hell goes on at that gym? Josh turns back to face them.
She thinks the train is leaving the station and she wants to be out front of it.
Somebody's' got to talk to Mrs. Bartlet. Tell her to get Becky Reeseman to back off.
[mumbles] I refuse to relay these instructions.
I'll talk to Lilly Mays.
I'll do it. I'm already going in there on the Ron Ehrlich thing.
Okay.
If I'm gonna take a hit, I might as well take two. [walks off and turns back]
Press upon her the following: It's taken 7 years to get the bill this far. It's locked down. Add this amendment and now I've got to go back in there and be nice to these people!
[nods] Yeah. [walks down the hall]
[loudly] Bring this one home, Sam. Sam pumps his fist in the air. Toby and Josh turn back to the Roosevelt Room.
[sighs] After you.
After you. Josh looks at Toby suspiciously then enters. Toby follows.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. DINER - DAY
Scenes.Description: Zoey and Charlie sit in a booth eating lunch. Gina sits at the counter nearby.

Dialogues.Line: It's called A Hundred...
[into cuff mic] I'll let you know when we're back on campus. [looks over at Zoey and Charlie]
...publishing.
Yeah.
I just read a review.
It's really great! It begins in the summer of 1900 when my grandmother was a child. [looks down at a notebook]
And I see you took notes. [takes the notebook]
You know why?
Cause you're totally anal?
No... [smiles] yes.
[reading] One hundred years ago the average life expectancy in the United States was 47?
Only 14% of the homes in this country had a bathtub.
[reading] 8% of the names had a telephone.
More than 95% of all births took place at home.
[reading] 90% of physicians had no college education. [smiles] This is a fun lunch, Zoey. We've got a little time travel thing going on.
[laughs] You really want some of my egg salad, don't you?
I really do. Zoey laughs and glances out the window. She looks back at Charlie nervously.
Do you have to get back to the office?
I've got a few minutes. Zoey nods after a moment.
I need to talk to you about Friday night.
I took back the suit.
Charlie, I...
I liked it, you didn't. That's ok. I'm here for you. I dress for you.
Listen...
I picked pick up a powdered blue tuxedo with ruffles.
Listen to me.
...and everything. I'm kidding about the tuxedo.
Listen to me. We can't go Friday night.
That's ok. [pause] Why not?
[pause] Charlie, you've been getting death threats.
From...
Yeah.
'Cause of you.
Because of me and you, yeah. Charlie looks hurt.
There's gonna be some kind of meeting or convention this weekend and... [glances at Gina] ...Secret Service just doesn't think...

[walks over] We've tried to secure the place Charlie. [sits down next to Zoey] We don't like it. Two many dark corners, back alleys doorways, windows. There's locks, a cellar. We can't secure the west end of the street.
[angry] I don't give a damn.
Charlie....
[angry] I don't give a damn! I bought a new suit. In fact, I've bought two now.
Charlie, we can't go.

Okay. [looks down at the notebook] Hey, look. It says here that a 100 years ago a black guy couldn't show up to a club opening with a white girl for fear he'd be killed. Zoey stares out the window, upset.
[to Gina] I have to go to the ladies room. Gina gets out and Zoey slides out.
[into cuff mic] Bookbag's up. [sits back down after Zoey leaves]
You know, if nothing else...I think if either one of us is gonna be pissed it ought to be me.
You're looking at the girl whose job it is to jump in front of a bullet. I like it when she stays in the dorm and watches videos.
[digs in his pockets] I gotta go. Is it all right to go? [throws down some money, grabs his coat and slides out]
Hey, come on! Tell her yourself.
I can't take this! [leaves]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - DAY
Scenes.Description: Sam passes the staffer in the hall.

Dialogues.Line: Hey there.
Hi. They stop.
Is Lilly in? She's expecting me.
You can go on in. Sam walks into LILLY'S OFFICE. Abbey leans against Lilly's desk. Sam looks surprised.
Hello, Sam.
Mrs. Bartlet.
Lilly tells me we have a problem.
Yes, ma'am.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. LILLY'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Sam and Abbey face each other.

Dialogues.Line: It's the tactics, Sam...
Mrs. Bartlet....

The strategizing. And I don't understand because we used to be very close. And now it seems to me I have a large and energetic staff who main function seems to be waging war with your staff. Is that accurate?
No ma'am. I don't think it is.
We're thoroughly professional.
No ma'am, I don't think you are.
I beg your pardon?
I like Lilly Mays. I think she's top notch, you know that. You know that it was hard for us to give her up.
Yes?
I think you're prone to amateur mistakes.
[stiffly] So, my staff is professional, just not me.
Mrs. Bartlet, you can't go on national television and decide to have a kid sit next to you on a whim. You gotta vet this stuff through my office.
What was the problem with the interview?
There was nothing wrong with the interview except it looked like you discovered there was a child labor problem because a 14-year-old boy named Jeffery just told you about it this morning.
I do not believe that is true.
And I don't not believe that exercise is gonna make me any healthier. But I didn't go to medical school, you did. You say so and I go to the gym.
Sam...
Mrs. Bartlet, I say this with all respect but you have to talk to Becky Reeseman and tell her not to offer that amendment tonight.
So, I will.
[surprised] Excuse me?
I said... I will.
[nods] Okay.
Is there anything else?
No, ma'am.
Okay. [leaves]
[quietly] Thank you, ma'am. [exits]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. OUTER OVAL OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Danny waits in a chair. Charlie shuffles through papers. Mrs. Landingham looks at Danny then goes back to her work.

Dialogues.Line: How you doing. Mrs. Landingham?
[smiles] Fine. Thank you, Danny.
[smiles] You keep glancing over like you're afraid I'm gonna steal something.
[smiles] No, I'm just not used to having members of the print media in here.
[smiles] I'll try not to get ink on the furniture.
[smiles sweetly] Aw Danny. and I was just about to offer you a cookie.
And now?
No. [grabs some folders and stands up.] Charlie, I'll be back in a few minutes. Abbey enters from the Colonnade. Danny stands.
Good evening, Mrs. Bartlet. [leaves]
Good evening, ma'am.
Hello! Are you covering the event?
The Many Women of Michigan?
The Michigan Women's Democratic Caucus?
Ah.
[smiles] Yes.
No. Actually, I'm here to see the President.
[surprised] Really?
Yes.
[pause] Okay. She plasters on a fake smile and heads towards the Mural Room. Danny glances at Charlie and sits back down.
So, what's up?
Not too much.
I saw you guys are going to the opening on Friday.
No.
No?
Security.
Is Zoey bothered?
You know, Danny, but I say it here and 10 million people read about tomorrow.
Thanks for the boost in my circulation but I'm actually off the record up here.
[looks down] It's not going to work.
What's not going to work?
You know what I'm talking about.
You and Zoey?
Yeah.
Why?
[angry] Look, I do what I do...I go where I go. If it's a problem for the Secret Service that I'm black...
Whoa....
...then that's the way it is. But she shouldn't expect candy and flowers, you know what I mean?
[gets up] I know what you're saying. But I don't' think the problem is you're black. I think the problem is you're stupid.
Well, thanks, Danny. You picked me right up.

You bet. Listen, the Hardy Boys in the letters they're talking about, they may be heavily armed but I wouldn't put a lot of money on their marksmanship. One of these days they're gonna miss her and hit me. Two thousand marriage proposals, 2,000 death threats, a dozen bodyguards. Everyone wants to get close. Everyone wants a thing. Plus, and I say this standing fifteen feet from the Oval Office, life with father couldn't have been a real company picnic, you know. If it was me, just for now, I'd make sure I was the one guy in her life who was hassle free. That's just me. Charlie stands as Bartlet opens the door to the Oval Office and steps in.
Danny...
Yes, sir. Bartlet smiles and motions for Danny to follow him. He slaps Danny on the arm and escorts him into THE OVAL OFFICE. Leo is sitting on the couch.
Please. [motions to the couch]
Hey, Danny.
Good evening, Leo.
Yes. Danny and Bartlet sit down.
I'd just like to say right off the bat that I strongly urged the President not to have this conversation. So I'm just a guy sitting here.
[smiles] We note with surprise your lack of conviction, Leo.
[grimly] Note it well, Sir. Danny returns Bartlet's smile. It grows awkward.
I miss our late night talks, Danny.
Yes, sir.
[smiles warmly] Out there in the campaign trail.... Ames, Iowa...Tulsa... Skokie, Center City, Tallahassee, Albany...San Antonio, Jasper, Wyoming.
[smiles] Yes, sir.
[nods and smiles] We got very close.
I'm flattered by that, sir.
You covered the First Lady as well.
Yes, sir.
You literally wrote the book on my wife.
Yes, sir. [laughs]
Once again I want to emphasize the strong personal bond we built on the campaign...
[grimaces] Oh, for God's sake.
Mr. President, did you call me in to ask me if I knew who the sources are close to the First Lady?
[shifts uncomfortably] Well, I was... going to... [looks at Leo] ...in a... proper... gentlemanly...
Even Byzantine...
...way... [glares at Leo]
[shakes head] No... no... no.
Danny.
No... no, sir.
You must save me from having this conversation with my wife.
Mr. President...
Or at least make it seem like I'm better armed than I evidently am.
I'm sorry, Mr. President.
[scowls] Danny...
I'd be revealing someone else's source.
We're off the record.
Also, I'd get in trouble with the First Lady!
Welcome to the club, Danny. We had some jackets made.
Let him go.
[sighs and smiles] Albany...Tulsa, Wichita. [laughs] I'm not kidding...a personal bond here, Danny.
Sir, if makes you feel any better I just gave some very sage dating advice to Charlie Young.
[nervously] You're coaching my Personal Aide on how to best score with my daughter? Yes, Danny, that does make me feel better.
Well, anything I can do to help, Mr. President.
Go away.
Thank you, Mr. President.
Thanks, Danny. Danny leaves.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. MURAL ROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: The room is crowded with groups of women talking. Josh and Donna stand among the crowd. Donna is drinking tea. Josh looks bored.

Dialogues.Line: It's an interesting book.
The Hundred Years ago thing?

Some medical authorities warned that professional seamstress were apt become sexually aroused by the steady rhythm of foot pedals. They recommended slipping bromide, which was thought to diminish a woman' sexual desires into their drinking water.
Why would anyone want to diminish a woman's sexual desires?
We can get out of hand. Josh looks surprised. They watch as Abbey enters.
Here we go. She walks over to a group of women, including Becky Reeseman.
Excuse me.
Good evening.
Would you mind if I had a word with Congresswoman Reeseman?
Well, sure!
I'll find you later. The other women leave.
[to Abbey] That's a beautiful suit.
Becky, did you decide to run for the Senate and not tell me?
[surprised] Abbey... [laughs nervously]
Cause you know Jed and I will be there with whatever you need.
I know the amendment comes as a bit of a surprise but...

Your Child Labor amendment is a poison pill. It will kill the GFTMAA is the following way: The Republican leadership will allow their guys to wear the black hats and they'll be released from a party line vote. This will surprised but not shock the Democratic leadership because they've seen it before. The vote will pass the House cause that's how sure they are that it will never pass the Senate and what's more you know it.
I felt like the train was leaving the station, Abbey.
When the trains leaving the station you'll know that too.
There is a Senate seat open you know.
And I'm sure the President will do what he can for you.
I've heard that before, Abbey.
We're not in the back of Steve's boat now, Becky. Don't bargain with me here.
I put this amendment back in my pocket like you told me to and I'm going to have problems of my own.
How many people know?
You, Steve, my staff, I'm sure by now the President's staff...
Then you're fine.
Wait. Excuse me. Am I supposed to trust the President's staff?
Yes. Are we done?
[pause] Yes.
Thank you. Reeseman watches her leave.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. OVAL OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Leo sits in a chair reading from the "Hundred Years" book to Bartlet.

Dialogues.Line: The rhythm of the sewing machine petals?

That's what it says. [reading] "Marijuana, heroin, morphine were all available over the counter in drug stores. According to one Pharmacist, heroin clears the completion, gives buoyancy to the mind, regulates the stomach and bowels and is in fact the perfect guardian of health." Now they tell me. Bartlet laughs. Mrs. Landingham knocks and enters.
Mr. President...
[jumps to his feet] I'm outta here.
Stay.
Right.
Chicken. Bartlet looks at his watch as Leo quickly leaves. Bartlet looks nervous. Abbey enters.
[tight smile] Hello.
Hello.
Hello, pumpkin. Mrs. Landingham closes the door. Abbey drops her suit coat over the back of a chair.
Abbey?
Hello, gumdrop.
[nervously] Listen... [quickly walks to the door and closes it]
[tight smile] Sam Seaborn came to see my Chief of Staff today. In fact, he did it twice.
Well, your Chief of Staff is a very attractive woman. Maybe he was, you know...
Jed...
Abbey, I told C.J. specifically...
Then C.J. got the signal wrong.
[contrite] No, she didn't.
What?
She didn't get the signal wrong. I wanted her to send someone.
Are you telling me...
This wire thing is a problem for me. The kid on TV was a mistake. And the amendment, from Becky Reeseman...
I just killed it.
...will bring down a trade bill that's been worked on for years.
I said I just killed it.
[nods] Fine.
Jed, we share a bed. Why didn't you just come to me?
I staffed it out to C.J..
[angry] You staffed it out.
That's right.
[angry] You don't staff me out. Bartlet paces, puts his hand on his head.
[angry] You don't give C.J. signals. You don't send Sam. And you don't bring Danny Concannon up here. [loudly] Don't handle me, Jed!
[yells, bangs on the desk] Then don't play me, Abbey! Don't work me! A lot of people around here think it was Lilly Mays, who planted you have a preference for Ron Erlich!
It wasn't Lilly Mays.
[loudly] I know it wasn't Lilly Mays. It was you!
[angry] Yes!
[angry] Yes!
Yes! And I'm sorry about that, but I wanted Ron to know that he had my support.
[angry] Well you put me in a bit of a spot there, Abigail. I name Ron Erlich now, which I was going to do anyway, and it makes me look like I'm taking instructions from my wife!
[loudly] Still it was wrong!
Are you talking about you or me?

[loudly] I'm talking about you. I'm talking about you sending people to me. And I tell you what else I'm talking about. I'm talking about you waiting a day to name a new fed chair, because thirty years ago the new fed chair was my boyfriend for six months.

[sternly] I'm talking about sending me messages through the press, and staking out agendas on morning shows. We are not going to be these people, Abbey. I'm not gonna do it! [loudly] I'll walk up to the hill right now, and I will give the Speaker of the House my resignation.
The house isn't in session.
[yelling] Do you want to see me get on the phone and put it in session?!
[clipped] Don't raise your voice to me!
[yelling] It was nine months, Abbey. Not six months. And I waited a day on Skippy, because the fed chair is a fairly important position, and I wanted to make damn sure my decision was right.
[yelling] You already made your decision!
How the hell do you know?
[yelling] You just said so. "I name Ron Erlich now, which I was gonna do anyway. It looks like I'm taking instructions from... my... wife!"
Yes.
Yes.
Yes. Bartlet paces as they both cool off.
Okay. So just ease up on the high ground.
On that point I concede the high ground.
Then I concede I was wrong about the thing.
Good.
However...
No, no however. Just be wrong. Just stand there in your wrongness and be wrong, and get used to it.
However...
Nine months, Abbey.
However...
Yes?
I'm still gonna kick your ass on child labor.
Abbey, please.
Jed, if it was one of our girls in that factory, you'd send in the Marines.
[looks thoughtful and nods] Yeah.
[quietly] Yeah.
Okay. [pause] We just had our first Oval Office fight.
[sighs] Yeah. Abbey turns and leans on the edge of his desk. Bartlet puts his hands in his pockets and walks around the desk.
Did you talk to Zoey today? [leans next to her, avoiding her gaze]
She went back to her dorm. She and Charlie had a fight cause the Service doesn't want them to show up at this thing together. [gazes at him]
Maybe she'll be so traumatized by this experience, that she'll never date another boy again.
Well, he left here a little while ago and...I'd say that in about an hour the lights will be off, there'll be a sock on the doorknob, and who...
Don't finish that sentence, I'm a man of questionable health. [glances at her sideways] The Michigan women are waiting for me.
Okay. Abbey smiles as he puts his arm around her shoulders and they walk towards the door. He drops her jacket around her shoulders and they exit.

Scenes.Scene Heading: DISSOLVE TO: INT. DORM HALLWAY - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Charlie walks up the crowded hallway with flowers. He stops and Zoey's door and knocks. While he waits, he turns and looks at Gina in the dorm room across the hall. She looks up at him from the book she's reading. Zoey answers her door and glares at Charlie.

Dialogues.Line: [quietly] Hi.
[coldly] Yes?
I came to apologize.
You left me sitting in a restaurant.
I feel bad about that.
Are there other things to feel bad about too?
Yes.
Name them, please.
Gina smiles at them.

Off the top of my head I wouldn't be able to give you a comprehensive list. Just suffice it to say that anything I've done to upset you even if it exists in your kind of confused little mind, I really apologize for.
[smiles and steps towards him] What did you bring me?
I brought you flowers. [hands her the flowers]
Oh, I can see that. What else?
A book. [hands her a book]
[reading] Introduction to Advanced Trigonometry. Gina laughs and puts down her book.
Your father made me pick it up.
What else?
Popcorn.
Why the popcorn?
'Cause I brought videos.
Get in here. Zoey smiles at him. Charlie smiles at Gina as Zoey pulls him inside and closes the door. Gina exits her room.
[into cuff mic] Bookbag is in for the night.

Scenes.Scene Heading: DISSOLVE TO: END TITLES.
